title: 106_s750
content: The "Compassionate Care Act of 1999" amends the Public Health Service Act to include a requirement relating to the rights of residents of certain facilities. The "Compassionate Care Act of 1999" mandates that healthcare facilities receiving federal funds must protect residents from abuse and restraints, which can only be used for safety reasons with a physician's written order specifying the duration. The "Compassionate Care Act of 1999" requires healthcare facilities to protect residents from abuse and restraints. Restraints can only be used with a physician's written order specifying the duration and circumstances, excluding emergency situations. Chemical restraints involve psychopharmacologic drugs for discipline or convenience, while physical restraints restrict movement for the same reasons. Seclusion is defined as separating a resident from the facility's general population for discipline or convenience, preventing them from returning when desired, and not for treating a medical symptom. This is in accordance with the "Compassionate Care Act of 1999" which regulates the use of restraints in healthcare facilities. "SEC. 582. REPORTING REQUIREMENT." The Protection and Advocacy for Mentally Ill Individuals Act of 1986 requires facilities to notify the appropriate system of each death within 7 days, including the resident's name and circumstances of death. Definitions for "facility" and "Protection and Advocacy system" are provided. The Protection and Advocacy for Mentally Ill Individuals Act of 1986 requires facilities to notify the appropriate system of each death within 7 days, including the resident's name and circumstances of death. The term "Protection and Advocacy system" refers to a system established under part C of the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act. SEC. 3 of the Protection and Advocacy for Mentally Ill Individuals Act of 1986 is amended to include investigating deaths or serious injuries of individuals with mental illness at applicable facilities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must establish regulations within a year of this Act's enactment, requiring facilities covered by the Protection and Advocacy for Mentally Ill Individuals Act of 1986 to meet specific requirements. These include maintaining appropriate staff levels, providing training on restraint use and alternatives, and ensuring accurate notification of deaths. The Act requires facilities to comply with specific requirements, including providing appropriate training and accurate notification of deaths. Non-compliance will result in ineligibility for participation in Federally funded programs.
